justification: The introduction remarks that "Several self-report measures aim to measure this (Lynch et al., 2010 …)", pointing to Lynch et al.’s (2010) Propensity to Plan Scale as a questionnaire for assessing how much people plan for the future.

The same sentence lists Strathman et al. (1994), the authors of the Consideration of Future Consequences Scale, indicating it is used to quantify how strongly individuals weigh distant versus immediate outcomes when planning.

Under "Mouselab-MDP Paradigm" the authors state: "We will use the Mouselab-MDP paradigm to measure human planning," establishing this process-tracing task as their instrument for estimating each person’s planning depth cost.

The discussion notes that earlier studies "assessed individual differences in planning by looking at people's scores in behavioral tasks such as the Tower of London (Daw, Niv, & Dayan, 2005; Krikorian, Bartok, & Gay, 1994)", explicitly citing this task as a planning measure.

Comparing instruments, the paper says its method exceeds "the two-step task (Daw et al., 2005) [which] only measures whether people plan at all," identifying the two-step task as an existing measure of engaging in planning.
